headline.seo: Michelle Obama’s Evolution as First Lady
headline.print_headline: First Lady’s Fraught White House Journey to Greater Fulfillment
headline.main: Michelle Obama and the Evolution of a First Lady

docs.abstract: New book The Obamas by New York Times reporter Jodi Kantor suggests that First Lady Michelle Obama's popular public persona belies a sometimes difficult transition to life in the White House, where she has clashed with some members of her husbands staff over their handling of several issues; interviews with dozens of current and former aides show that she has been an unrecognized force in her husband's administration and that her story has been one first of struggle, then turnaround and greater fulfillment.
docs.lead_paragraph: Mrs. Obama’s adjustment to the White House — including, at times, severe tension with her husband’s staff — illuminates some of President Obama’s central challenges.
docs.snippet: Mrs. Obama’s adjustment to the White House — including, at times, severe tension with her husband’s staff — illuminates some of President Obama’s central challenges.

headline.print_headline: Harder for Americans to Rise From Economy’s Lower Rungs
headline.main: Harder for Americans to Rise From Lower Rungs

docs.abstract: Many researchers say Americans enjoy less economic mobility than their peers in Canada and much of Western Europe in part because of poverty, family background and gaps between the rich and the rest; mobility gap has been widely discussed in academic circles, but a sour season of mass employment and street protests has moved the discussion toward center stage.
docs.lead_paragraph: Americans enjoy less economic mobility than their peers in Canada and much of Western Europe in part because of the depth of poverty, family background and the gaps between the rich and the rest.
docs.snippet: Americans enjoy less economic mobility than their peers in Canada and much of Western Europe in part because of the depth of poverty, family background and the gaps between the rich and the rest.

headline.main: Georgia's Tough Campaign Against Childhood Obesity

docs.abstract: Will Georgia's hard-hitting ads push families with obesity problems toward help, or toward anger and denial?
docs.snippet: Will Georgia's hard-hitting ads push families with obesity problems toward help, or toward anger and denial?

headline.main: Georgia's Tough Campaign Against Childhood Obesity

docs.abstract: Will Georgia's hard-hitting ads push families with obesity problems toward help, or toward anger and denial?
docs.lead_paragraph: The blogosphere hates Georgia's tough new Strong4Life campaign against childhood obesity. Short ads or billboards, each featuring an obese child (the youngest looks to be about 9, the oldest a teenager), tell Georgia to "stop sugarcoating" the problem. "Fat kids become fat adults," reads the slogan under what looks to be the youngest child, a little girl who can be seen in a brief video saying she hates to go to school, where kids make fun of her. Another ad, under a young boy, reads: "Big bones didn't make me this way. Big meals did."
docs.snippet: Will Georgia's hard-hitting ads push families with obesity problems toward help, or toward anger and denial?

headline.main: Behind the Cover Story: Tara Parker-Pope on Weight Loss

docs.abstract: The best and most surprising responses I have received are from several readers who start by telling me that they don't have a weight problem, but they now have a better understanding of the challenges overweight people face.
docs.snippet: The best and most surprising responses I have received are from several readers who start by telling me that they don't have a weight problem, but they now have a better understanding of the challenges overweight people face.

headline.main: Behind the Cover Story: Tara Parker-Pope on Weight Loss

docs.abstract: The best and most surprising responses I have received are from several readers who start by telling me that they don't have a weight problem, but they now have a better understanding of the challenges overweight people face.
docs.lead_paragraph: Tara Parker-Pope is the creator and writer of Well, a daily health blog and weekly column for The New York Times. She wrote this week's cover article, "The Fat Trap."
docs.snippet: The best and most surprising responses I have received are from several readers who start by telling me that they don't have a weight problem, but they now have a better understanding of the challenges overweight people face.

headline.main: Gingrich on the Culinary Trail in Iowa

docs.abstract: Never a svelte figure, Mr. Gingrich seems to have put on weight as the campaign has entered its seventh month.
docs.snippet: Never a svelte figure, Mr. Gingrich seems to have put on weight as the campaign has entered its seventh month.

headline.main: Gingrich on the Culinary Trail in Iowa

docs.abstract: Never a svelte figure, Mr. Gingrich seems to have put on weight as the campaign has entered its seventh month.
docs.lead_paragraph: INDEPENDENCE, Iowa -- Is it a coincidence that Newt Gingrich's long and winding bus tour has stopped at many food businesses?
docs.snippet: Never a svelte figure, Mr. Gingrich seems to have put on weight as the campaign has entered its seventh month.

headline.seo: New Year’s Resolutions, Recycled, Are a Boon for Business
headline.print_headline: I Just Got Here, But I Know Trouble When I See It: Those Recycled Resolutions Are a Boon for Business
headline.main: Your Recycled Resolutions Are a Boon for Business

docs.abstract: Self-improvement industry thrives on New Year’s resolutions gone awry; Americans were projected to spend $62 billion in 2011 on self-improvement in the hope of keeping resolutions; some stop-smoking and weight-loss programs, as well as gyms, are trying to help for the long haul, a strategy that can improve customers' chances of success and build brand loyalty and revenue.
docs.lead_paragraph: The self-improvement industry thrives on New Year’s resolutions gone awry. After all, if you don’t lose those pounds or stop smoking this year, you’ll probably try again in 2013.
docs.snippet: The self-improvement industry thrives on New Year’s resolutions gone awry. After all, if you don’t lose those pounds or stop smoking this year, you’ll probably try again in 2013.

docs.abstract: Tara Parker-Pope article highlights research done by University of Melbourne professor Dr Joseph Proietto on obesity, which was published in The New England Journal of Medicine and has caused a stir in the weight-loss community; Proietto and his colleagues have found that the human body continues to fight against weight loss long after dieting has stopped, and adds to a growing body of evidence that challenges conventional thinking about obesity.
docs.lead_paragraph: In the battle to lose weight, and keep it off, our bodies are fighting against us.
docs.snippet: In the battle to lose weight, and keep it off, our bodies are fighting against us.
